May 25, 1986: Fiction
I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi
Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing.
A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carr√©. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a
British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man.
THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The
hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into
conflict with the West.
LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in
a small Minnesota town.
THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues
her adventures in the prehistoric world.
BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter
family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing.
THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's
attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion.
LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman
caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan.
HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A
semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan.
THE ENEMY WITHIN, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) The third
volume in the ''Mission Earth'' science fiction series.
SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $17.95.) A
businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor.
THE SONGS OF DISTANT EARTH, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine,
$17.95.) Two groups of colonists from Earth meet on a paradisiacal planet.
HIGH HEARTS, by Rita Mae Brown. (Bantam, $17.95.) The experiences of a
Virginia belle who joins the Confederate cavalry.
THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the
America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the
services assigned to them.
THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM, by Marek Halter. (Holt, $19.95.) One hundred
generations in the life of a Jewish family.
Non-Fiction
FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and
ruminations from the television star and father of five.
YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at
the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults.
THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS, by David A. Stockman. (Harper & Row, $21.95.)
Why President Reagan was unable to balance the budget.
ENTER TALKING, by Joan Rivers with Richard Meryman. (Delacorte, $17.95.)
The talk-show hostess' long professional climb.
BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip
with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love.
WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner.
(Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.''
BESS W. TRUMAN, by Margaret Truman. (Macmillan, $19.95.) Her daughter
shows that the former First Lady was intelligent and caring as well as private and
austere.
JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.)
Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal.
NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a
series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them in order to grow.
THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit,
$15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological
disabilities.
BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. (Knopf, $17.95.) The
autobiography of the distinguished English actor.
IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam,
$19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler.
ALL GOD'S CHILDREN NEED TRAVELING SHOES, by Maya Angelou. (Random
House, $15.95.) A writer's memoir carries the story from her native Arkansas to
her ancestral Ghana.
ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for
76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic.
THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. Crown, $18.95.) The life and loves of J.
Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world.
